subsection.title: Orthogonal diagonalization of a symmetric matrix

example.p:
Here we will carry out on the symmetric matrix
S = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix} . The characteristic polynomial is c_S(\lambda) = \lambda^2 (\lambda - 2) (\lambda + 2) , so the eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = 0, \lambda_2 = 2, and \lambda_3 = -2.

Solving the homogeneous system (2 I - S) \uvec{x} = \zerovec leads to E_2(S) = \Span \left\{ \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \right\} . Solving the homogeneous system (-2 I - S) \uvec{x} = \zerovec leads to E_{-2}(S) = \Span \left\{ \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ -1 \\ 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \right\} . Solving the homogeneous system (0 I - S) \uvec{x} = \zerovec leads to
E_0(S) = \Span \left\{ \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right], \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right\} . Notice that these four eigenvectors form an orthogonal set. In particular, the two basis vectors for E_0(S) are already orthogonal. If they had not turned out that way from just solving the system, we could have applied the Gram-Schmidt process to just those two vectors to obtain an orthogonal basis for that eigenspace.

Normalizing our eigenvectors leads to the orthonormal basis
E_0(S) = \Span \left\{ \frac{1}{2} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \frac{1}{2} \left[\begin{array}{r} 1 \\ -1 \\ 1 \\ -1 \end{array}\right], \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \left[\begin{array}{r} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right], \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \left[\begin{array}{r} 0 \\ -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right\}
for \R^n. Placing these four orthonormal vectors into a transition matrix
P = \left[\begin{array}{crrr} \frac{1}{2} \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp - \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \amp 0 \\ \frac{1}{2} \amp - \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \amp - \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \frac{1}{2} \amp \frac{1}{2} \amp \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \amp 0 \\ \frac{1}{2} \amp - \frac{1}{2} \amp 0 \amp \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \end{array}\right]
allows us to orthogonally diagonalize S as \utrans{P} S P = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ \amp -2 \\ \amp \amp 0 \\ \amp \amp \amp 0 \end{bmatrix} .

subsection.title: Unitary diagonalization of a Hermitian matrix
subsection.p: is for real symmetric matrices, but it can be applied without modification to complex Hermitian matrices.

example.p: Here we will attempt to unitarily diagonalize the Hermitian matrix H = \left[\begin{array}{rcr} 1 \amp 1 \amp \ci \\ 1 \amp 1 \amp -\ci \\ -\ci \amp \ci \amp 1 \end{array}\right] . The characteristic polynomial is c_H(\lambda) = (\lambda + 1) (\lambda - 2)^2 , so the eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = -1, \lambda_2 = 2.

example.title: Gram-Schmidt can't fix everything
example.p: Let's attempt to unitarily diagonalize the matrix A = \left[\begin{array}{cr} \ci \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp -\ci \end{array}\right] . The characteristic polynomial is c_A(\lambda) = (\lambda - \ci)(\lambda + \ci) , so the eigenvalues are \lambda_1 = \ci, \lambda_2 = - \ci.

Solving the homogeneous system (\ci I - A) \uvec{x} = \zerovec leads to E_{\ci}(A) = \Span \left\{ \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ci \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \right\} . Solving the homogeneous system (- \ci I - A) \uvec{x} = \zerovec leads to E_{-\ci}(A) = \Span \left\{ \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \right\} . These eigenvectors are not orthogonal, so let's attempt to fix that using the process. Write \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2 for the two eigenvectors we have above. As usual, we start with \uvec{e}_1 = \uvec{v}_1, and then correct \uvec{v}_w to
\uvec{e}_2 = \uvec{v}_2 - \frac{\inprod{\uvec{v}_2}{\uvec{e}_1}}{\norm{\uvec{e}_1}^2} \, \uvec{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} - \frac{1}{5} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ci \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} - \frac{2 \ci}{5} \\ \frac{4}{5} \end{bmatrix} . Now we normalize to get orthonormal set
\left\{ \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ci \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \left[\begin{array}{r} - \ci \\ 2 \end{array}\right] \right\} . Using these vectors as columns, we obtain unitary matrix U = \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \left[\begin{array}{cr} 2 \ci \amp - \ci \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right] . Check whether U unitarily diagonalizes A:
\inv{U} A U = \adjoint{U} A U \amp = \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \left[\begin{array}{rc} 2 \ci \amp 1 \\ - \ci \amp 2 \end{array}\right] \cdot \left[\begin{array}{cr} \ci \amp 0 \\ 1 \amp - \ci \end{array}\right] \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{5}} \left[\begin{array}{cr} 2 \ci \amp - \ci \\ 1 \amp 2 \end{array}\right]
\amp = \frac{1}{5} \left[\begin{array}{cr} 5 \ci \amp -5 \ci \\ 0 \amp -5 \ci \end{array}\right]
\amp = \left[\begin{array}{cr} i \amp -\ci \\ 0 \amp -\ci \end{array}\right]
. What happened? By applying the Gram-Schmidt process across eigenspaces instead of just within a particular eigenspace, we have replaced the second eigenvector \uvec{v}_2 by a vector that is orthogonal to the first eigenvector \uvec{v}_1, as required, but this replacement for \uvec{v}_2 was no longer an eigenvector. To diagonalize a matrix, the transition matrix must have columns which are linearly independent eigenvectors. But in the end only one column of our unitary U was an eigenvector for A.

subsection.title: Unitary diagonalization of a normal matrix

example.p:
Notice that the basis vector for E_{3 \ci}(N) is already orthogonal to each of the basis vectors for E_3(N), as expected. But the basis for E_3(N) is not orthogonal, so we will need to apply the process to those two vectors. Labelling those two vectors as \uvec{v}_1 and \uvec{v}_2, we may keep \uvec{e}_1 = \uvec{v}_1, but we must adjust
\uvec{e}_2 = \uvec{v}_2 - \frac{\inprod{\uvec{v}_2}{\uvec{e}_1}}{\norm{\uvec{e}_1}^2} \, \uvec{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} - \frac{- \ci}{2} \begin{bmatrix} \ci \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{1}{2} \\ 1 \\ \frac{\ci}{2} \end{bmatrix} . We now have an orthogonal set of eigenvectors which we can normalize to obtain an orthonormal set
\left\{ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \begin{bmatrix} \ci \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{6}} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ \ci \end{bmatrix}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \left[\begin{array}{r} -\ci \\ \ci \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right\} .
